Line 179: Line 179:
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 Killed' So Far in Egypt Protests|publisher=''[[South African Press Association]]'' (via ''[[News24]]'')|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile banks are closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money, prices are skyrocketing as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galal |first=Ola |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-soaring-food-prices-by-day-looters-at-night-amid-turmoil.html |title=Egyptians Face Food Inflation by Day, Looters by Night |work=[[Bloomberg]] |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 Killed' So Far in Egypt Protests|publisher=''[[South African Press Association]]'' (via ''[[News24]]'')|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile banks are closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money, prices are skyrocketing as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galal |first=Ola |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-soaring-food-prices-by-day-looters-at-night-amid-turmoil.html |title=Egyptians Face Food Inflation by Day, Looters by Night |work=[[Bloomberg]] |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
â
In the late evening (23:00 local Egyptian time) President Mubarak proclaimed that he did not intend to run for another term in the next election.<ref>[http://www.charter.net/video/play/429076/channels/cnn]. charter.net.</ref> Mubarak said he would stay in office to insure a peaceful transition to the next election, [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|set for September 2011]], and promised to make political reforms. He also said that he would demand that Egyptian authorities pursue "outlaws" and "investigate those who caused the security disarray." Mubarak said that peaceful protests were transformed into "unfortunate clashes, mobilised and controlled by political forces that wanted to escalate and worsen the situation. Mubarak aslo called upon the [[Parliament of Egypt]] to change the limit terms of the presidency and change the requirements to run for president. He also accepted the legal charges against the parliament members which means a great amount of the parliament members will be changed through the legal prosses."<ref>[http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7102JP20110201?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true]. ''[[Reuters]]''.</ref> Crowds continued protesting in Tahrir Square, demanding that the president step down.<ref>[http://www.charter.net/video/play/429085/channels/cnn]. charter.net.</ref><ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121191413252982.html]. ''[[Al Jazeera English]]''.</ref> There were reports that Mubarak's proclamation came after President Barack Obama's special envoy, [[Frank G. Wisner]], told Mubarak the U.S. saw his presidency at an end and urged him to prepare for an orderly transition to real democracy.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110201/D9L48QIO0.html "Obama Envoy Told Mubarak Tenure Coming to a Close]. apnews.myway.com.</ref>
+
In the late evening (23:00 local Egyptian time) President Mubarak proclaimed that he did not intend to run for another term in the next election.<ref>[http://www.charter.net/video/play/429076/channels/cnn]. charter.net.</ref> Mubarak said he would stay in office to insure a peaceful transition to the next election, [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|set for September 2011]], and promised to make political reforms. He also said that he would demand that Egyptian authorities pursue "outlaws" and "investigate those who caused the security disarray." Mubarak said that peaceful protests were transformed into "unfortunate clashes, mobilised and controlled by political forces that wanted to escalate and worsen the situation. Mubarak aslo called upon the [[Parliament of Egypt|Egyptian parliament]] to change the limit terms of the presidency and change the requirements to run for president. He also accepted the legal charges against the parliament members which means a great amount of the parliament members will be changed through the legal prosses."<ref>[http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7102JP20110201?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true]. ''[[Reuters]]''.</ref> Crowds continued protesting in Tahrir Square, demanding that the president step down.<ref>[http://www.charter.net/video/play/429085/channels/cnn]. charter.net.</ref><ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121191413252982.html]. ''[[Al Jazeera English]]''.</ref> There were reports that Mubarak's proclamation came after President Barack Obama's special envoy, [[Frank G. Wisner]], told Mubarak the U.S. saw his presidency at an end and urged him to prepare for an orderly transition to real democracy.<ref>[http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110201/D9L48QIO0.html "Obama Envoy Told Mubarak Tenure Coming to a Close]. apnews.myway.com.</ref>
